review.title: Towards the Ontology Web Search Engine
review.abstract: The project of the Ontology Web Search Engine is presented in this paper. The main purpose of this paper is to develop such a project that can be easily implemented. Ontology Web Search Engine is software to look for and index ontologies in the Web. OWL (Web Ontology Languages) ontologies are meant, and they are necessary for the functioning of the SWES (Semantic Web Expert System). SWES is an expert system that will use found ontologies from the Web, generating rules from them, and will supplement its knowledge base with these generated rules. It is expected that the SWES will serve as a universal expert system for the average user.

metadata.title: TOWARDS THE ONTOLOGY WEB SEARCH ENGINE

sections.text: It is a project that can be easily implemented. Ontology Web Search Engine is a software that is essentially looking for and index ontologies on the Web. OWL (Web Ontology Languages) ontologies are meant, and they are necessary for the functioning of SWES (Semantic Web Expert System). SWES is an expert system that uses found ontologies from the Web, which generate rules from it, and will supplement its knowledge base with these generated rules. SWES is expected to serve as a universal expert system for the average user. Keywords: Ontology Web Search Engine, Crawler, Indexer, Semantic WebI. INTRODUCTIONS The technological development of the Web in recent decades has provided us with more information than we can effectively understand or manage.

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text: The term "Semantic Web" was coined more than 10 years ago by Tim Berners-Lee to discover the potential of SWD components across the Web. [7] Since then, this term has been used and quickly filled with content. During this time, semantic web technologies have been actively developed, so it was not surprising that the task of ontology search on the Web has already been investigated and even implemented. There are several implemented ontology web search engines and let's analyze them to look at them individually. SWOGLE was the first search engine for the Semantic Web, and the main contribution of SWOGLE was Li Ding [8]. SWOGLE is positioned as a crawler-based indexing and retrieval system for the Semantic Web documents, including the RDF (Resource Description Framework) and OWL [9]. SWOGLE consists of four key components SWD (Semantic Web Document) discovery, metadata analysis, data interface, and interface.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The project aims to develop a web search engine for the search and indexing of OWL ontologies on the web [3]. In the course of the project description, the achievements of the search engine technology were considered, the typical structure of a web search engine was described, ontology web search strategies were identified, related work in the field of ontology search was overlooked, and also the structure of the ontology web search engine was presented. This structure was described in detail in order to have the possibility of realizing the project as soon as possible. It seems that OWL ontologies cannot completely replace regular websites. At least, it can be argued that this will not happen in the near future. In fact, this is a really difficult task, taking into account the distributed nature of the web. Such a situation contradicts the purpose that this knowledge can be generated regularly in order to use the side of the SWES system (a rule designed so that all websites can be converted in the near future).

Despite the differences of web search engines, the typical structure of a web search engine comprises four essential modules [18]:
Crawlers are computer programs that browse the Web [18].
The indexer takes all the words from each document in the page repository and records the URL, where each word occurred [18].
The web query engine receives the search requests from users [18].
The page repository stores the Web content that was retrieved during the crawling process [18].
